articles.headline: Lone $4.1 Billion Sale Led to ‘Flash Crash’ in May
articles.snippet: Regulators said they had identified the sequence of events that erased more than 600 points from the Dow in minutes.
articles.abstract: Regulators said they had identified the sequence of events that erased more than 600 points from the Dow in minutes.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a stock market mystery that had everyone guessing for months: just what caused that harrowing flash crash last May?

articles.headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Overhauling F.A.O. Schwarz Brand
articles.snippet: Toys “R” Us will try to invigorate a sagging business for the holidays by opening F. A. O. sections in all of its stores and redesigning the logo and toys.
articles.abstract: Toys “R” Us will try to invigorate a sagging business for the holidays by opening F. A. O. sections in all of its stores and redesigning the logo and toys.
articles.lead_paragraph: F. A. O. Schwarz’s crowning moment came when Tom Hanks, in the movie “Big,” jumped onto a giant piano in the toy store and plunked out “Heart and Soul.”

articles.headline: Still Stuck in Denial on Wall St.
articles.snippet: A hedge fund manager who feels beat up on — and can’t imagine why — might need a reality check.
articles.abstract: A hedge fund manager who feels beat up on — and can’t imagine why — might need a reality check.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are some things Anthony Scaramucci would like you to know about him, right up front.

articles.headline: In Mortgage Ad, Two Wrongs Don’t Make a Right
articles.snippet: ING Direct says it prides itself on telling the truth. But it has been less than completely candid in peddling its latest mortgage offering.
articles.abstract: ING Direct says it prides itself on telling the truth. But it has been less than completely candid in peddling its latest mortgage offering.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most important lessons of the mortgage collapse is that potential borrowers need clear explanations of exactly what kind of commitment they are making.

articles.headline: Bank of America to Freeze Foreclosure Cases
articles.snippet: It is the third major lender in the last two weeks to say it is freezing foreclosures and its decision could involve tens of thousands of pending foreclosure cases.
articles.abstract: It is the third major lender in the last two weeks to say it is freezing foreclosures and its decision could involve tens of thousands of pending foreclosure cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America, the country’s largest mortgage lender by assets, said on Friday that it was reviewing documents in all foreclosure cases now in court to evaluate if there were errors.

articles.headline: Atlanta Hats? Seattle Socks? Macy’s Goes Local
articles.snippet: After decades of acquiring and centralizing, Macy’s has increased sales by rediscovering its multiple local roots.
articles.abstract: After decades of acquiring and centralizing, Macy’s has increased sales by rediscovering its multiple local roots.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA  Long before it was renamed Macy’s, the department store of choice here was Rich’s. Opening just after the Civil War, it drew generations of Atlantans with its coconut cake and the Pink Pig, a Christmastime children’s train.

articles.headline: Mexico Seeks to Unify Police to Fight Drugs
articles.snippet: The proposal to alter the nation’s police comes at a critical moment for President Felipe Calderón, who faces pressure to demonstrate progress in defeating the drug cartels.
articles.abstract: The proposal to alter the nation’s police comes at a critical moment for President Felipe Calderón, who faces pressure to demonstrate progress in defeating the drug cartels.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Mexico  The Mexican government is preparing a plan to radically alter the nation’s police forces, hoping not only to instill a trust the public has never had in them but also to choke off a critical source of manpower for organized crime.

articles.headline: Deal Near for ‘Hobbit’ Films in 3-D
articles.snippet: A deal between Warner and MGM could allow the director to begin shooting J. R. R. Tolkien’s “Hobbit” next year.
articles.abstract: A deal between Warner and MGM could allow the director to begin shooting J. R. R. Tolkien’s “Hobbit” next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  “The Hobbit” is almost out of movie jail.

articles.headline: In California Bid, Whitman Spends Record but Struggles
articles.snippet: Meg Whitman has had trouble mastering the state’s vast and convoluted electoral landscape despite spending $119 million of her own money on the race.
articles.abstract: Meg Whitman has had trouble mastering the state’s vast and convoluted electoral landscape despite spending $119 million of her own money on the race.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Meg Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor in California, passed a milestone the other day, investing $119 million of her own money into her campaign, breaking a record held by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York.

articles.headline: House Majority Still Uncertain, Republicans Say
articles.snippet: Enough contests remain fluid that both parties head into the final four weeks of the campaign able to change the dynamic before Election Day.
articles.abstract: Enough contests remain fluid that both parties head into the final four weeks of the campaign able to change the dynamic before Election Day.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Republicans carry substantial advantages as they move into the final month of the fall campaign, but the resilience of vulnerable Democrats is complicating Republican efforts to lock down enough seats to capture the House and take control of the unsettled electoral battleground.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Supreme Court Term Offers Hot Issues and Future Hints
articles.snippet: The term’s cases will be scrutinized for insights on the the court’s newest member, Justice Elena Kagan, and for hints about how the court will rule when even more highly charged cases reach it.
articles.abstract: The term’s cases will be scrutinized for insights on the the court’s newest member, Justice Elena Kagan, and for hints about how the court will rule when even more highly charged cases reach it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The new Supreme Court term, which begins Monday, includes cases on some of the most contested issues of the day, including protests at military funerals, illegal immigration, support for religious schools, violent video games, DNA evidence and prosecutorial misconduct.

articles.headline: Side Effects May Include Lawsuits
articles.snippet: Antipsychotic drugs are the top-selling pharmaceuticals in America. But with the surge in use has come an increase in questions — and lawsuits — about aggressive marketing and the scientific soundness of drug companies’ studies.
articles.abstract: Antipsychotic drugs are the top-selling pharmaceuticals in America. But with the surge in use has come an increase in questions — and lawsuits — about aggressive marketing and the scientific soundness of drug companies’ studies.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR decades, antipsychotic drugs were a niche product. Today, they’re the top-selling class of pharmaceuticals in America, generating annual revenue of about $14.6 billion and surpassing sales of even blockbusters like heart-protective statins.

articles.headline: Mark Zuckerberg’s Most Valuable Friend
articles.snippet: In various ways, Sheryl Sandberg seems the opposite of her boss, Mark Zuckerberg. But she has helped him navigate Facebook’s vast expansion.
articles.abstract: In various ways, Sheryl Sandberg seems the opposite of her boss, Mark Zuckerberg. But she has helped him navigate Facebook’s vast expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.

articles.headline: Count on Sequels to TARP
articles.snippet: For all the talk of the success of the Troubled Asset Relief Program, be wary of claims that financial reform fixed the notion of too-big-to-fail.
articles.abstract: For all the talk of the success of the Troubled Asset Relief Program, be wary of claims that financial reform fixed the notion of too-big-to-fail.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE government is pulling a sheet over TARP, the Troubled Asset Relief Program created during the panic of 2008 to bail out the nation’s financial institutions. With the program’s expiration on Sunday, we can expect to hear lots of claims from the folks at the Treasury that it was a great success.

articles.headline: Las Vegas Faces Its Deepest Slide Since the 1940s
articles.snippet: There are many cities that are beginning to see the first glimpses of recession’s end. Las Vegas is not one of them.
articles.abstract: There are many cities that are beginning to see the first glimpses of recession’s end. Las Vegas is not one of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — There are many cities across the country that are beginning to see the first glimpses of the end of the recession.

articles.headline: For Female Marines, Tea Comes With Bullets
articles.snippet: In Marja, Afghanistan, female Marines have daily skirted Pentagon rules restricting women in combat.
articles.abstract: In Marja, Afghanistan, female Marines have daily skirted Pentagon rules restricting women in combat.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan  They expected tea, not firefights.

articles.headline: More States Allowing Guns in Bars
articles.snippet: Gun rights advocates applauded four states that recently enacted laws allowing loaded guns in bars.
articles.abstract: Gun rights advocates applauded four states that recently enacted laws allowing loaded guns in bars.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE  Happy-hour beers were going for $5 at Past Perfect, a cavernous bar just off this city’s strip of honky-tonks and tourist shops when Adam Ringenberg walked in with a loaded 9-millimeter pistol in the front pocket of his gray slacks.

articles.headline: Film Version of Zuckerberg Divides Generations
articles.snippet: The film about Facebook’s founder, Mark Zuckerberg, can be viewed as a cautionary tale or something to applaud.
articles.abstract: The film about Facebook’s founder, Mark Zuckerberg, can be viewed as a cautionary tale or something to applaud.
articles.lead_paragraph: At what point does ambition, a cornerstone of American commerce, morph into something darker and less celebrated? Over the weekend, people who saw “The Social Network,” the movie about Facebook and its principal creator, Mark Zuckerberg, were left to ponder that question on the sidewalk.

articles.headline: 2 Brothers Await Broad Use of Medical E-Records
articles.snippet: After more than a decade, Dr. Tom Doerr and his brother, John, see a possible turning point for their business with Apple’s iPad and a national mandate for digital medical records.
articles.abstract: After more than a decade, Dr. Tom Doerr and his brother, John, see a possible turning point for their business with Apple’s iPad and a national mandate for digital medical records.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no silver bullet for reforming America’s health care system, but medical experts have long agreed that digital patient records and electronic prescribing can help improve care and curb costs.

articles.headline: Verizon Wireless to Pay Millions in Refunds
articles.snippet: Verizon Wireless will pay up to $90 million to 15 million cellphone customers who were wrongly charged, one of the largest-ever refunds by a telecommunications company.
articles.abstract: Verizon Wireless will pay up to $90 million to 15 million cellphone customers who were wrongly charged, one of the largest-ever refunds by a telecommunications company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Verizon Wireless said on Sunday that it would pay up to $90 million in refunds to 15 million cellphone customers who were wrongly charged for data sessions or Internet use, one of the largest customer refunds by a telecommunications company.

articles.headline: Lehman Omnipresent in Nomura’s Push Into U.S.
articles.snippet: Former Lehman Brothers employees have reunited at the American headquarters of a Japanese brokerage giant.
articles.abstract: Former Lehman Brothers employees have reunited at the American headquarters of a Japanese brokerage giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: The discreet sign by the door does not say Lehman Brothers. But step inside: a bit of Lehman lives on here in Manhattan.

articles.headline: No Stopping Movie View of Mark Zuckerberg
articles.snippet: As a public figure, Facebook’s founder would have to prove reckless disregard for the truth if he wanted to address the portrayal of him in the film “The Social Network.”
articles.abstract: As a public figure, Facebook’s founder would have to prove reckless disregard for the truth if he wanted to address the portrayal of him in the film “The Social Network.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of the moviegoers who made “The Social Network” the top box-office draw of the weekend saw an unflattering portrayal of Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook.

articles.headline: As Maliki Clings to Power, Iraq’s Fissures Deepen
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, all but assured of a second term, must now overcome Iraq’s divisions.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, all but assured of a second term, must now overcome Iraq’s divisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  When Nuri Kamal al-Maliki began his bid for re-election as prime minister  exactly a year ago on Saturday  he pledged to unite a population splintered and suspicious after years of war. He has not, and while he is hardly alone in blame, the consequences could haunt Iraq for years to come.

articles.headline: Casinos Now See Online Gambling as a Better Bet
articles.snippet: A trade group for major casinos like Harrah’s Entertainment and MGM Resorts is working on a proposal to ask Congress to legalize some form of online gambling.
articles.abstract: A trade group for major casinos like Harrah’s Entertainment and MGM Resorts is working on a proposal to ask Congress to legalize some form of online gambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many of the country’s largest casinos, long opposed to gambling games like poker on the Internet, are now having second thoughts.

articles.headline: Flawed Paperwork Aggravates a Foreclosure Crisis
articles.snippet: Procedural problems at some large lenders are so prevalent that additional lenders and loan servicers are likely to halt foreclosure proceedings, experts say.
articles.abstract: Procedural problems at some large lenders are so prevalent that additional lenders and loan servicers are likely to halt foreclosure proceedings, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: As some of the nation’s largest lenders have conceded that their foreclosure procedures might have been improperly handled, lawsuits have revealed myriad missteps in crucial documents.

articles.headline: Cheap Debt for Corporations Fails to Spur Economy
articles.snippet: Companies keep saving, waiting for the economy to improve, but it is unlikely to improve if they keep saving.
articles.abstract: Companies keep saving, waiting for the economy to improve, but it is unlikely to improve if they keep saving.
articles.lead_paragraph: As many households and small businesses are being turned away by bank loan officers, large corporations are borrowing vast sums of money for next to nothing  simply because they can.

articles.headline: Mass Rapes in Congo Reveals U.N. Weakness
articles.snippet: Despite years of experience and billions of dollars, the peacekeeping force still seems to be failing at its task of protecting civilians.
articles.abstract: Despite years of experience and billions of dollars, the peacekeeping force still seems to be failing at its task of protecting civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUVUNGI, Democratic Republic of Congo — Four armed men barged into Anna Mburano’s hut, slapped the children and threw them down. They flipped Mrs. Mburano on her back, she said, and raped her, repeatedly.
